Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Made in USA-Profitably: An Integrated Design Tool for Eliminating Assembly
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/ commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in revolutionizing the current mechanical system design practice across multiple industry sectors. Rather than using multiple rigid parts to create a mechanical system, our compliant design method, inspired by designs in nature, exploits material elasticity to create one-piece compliant systems or joint-less mechanisms. Our compliant design software will provide designers with a powerful tool to create products with dramatic reductions in part count, thereby reducing manufacturing cost ( at times eliminating assembly operations altogether), enhancing reliability and precision in ways that could not be achieved through conventional design methods. By replacing assembly-intensive products with compliant designs that have substantially lower assembly burden, manufacturing in the U.S. could be more competitive. For example, our compliant wiper has 75% fewer parts, weighs 50% less, and costs 60% less to manufacture in Detroit compared to conventional multi-piece wiper that is made in China. Thus, technically skilled machine operators producing one-piece designs would create value locally, without the burden of shipping costs and delays, to tip business equation away from offshoring. Thus, broad adoption of compliant design as enabled by our software will lead to more "Made-in-USA" products.




This project seeks to develop a framework for Integrated Computer Aided Engineering software for compliant designs. While commercially available design software can assist users in evaluating conventional mechanisms with rigid links and joints, there is no readily available software tool on the market to create (synthesize) and optimize the design of compliant mechanical solutions. Compliant design synthesis algorithms seen in existing research literature often require specialized knowledge that "non-足expert" users might not have, and the algorithms are often not robust enough to consistently create feasible designs. In Phase I, we laid the theoretical and the computational foundation needed to develop a unified compliant design framework. Starting with functional design specifications such as desired motion output(s), and input actuator(s), the algorithms will (a) determine an optimum topology (i.e., how material should be distributed within a prescribed 2D or 3D space), and (b) optimize the size, shape and geometry to meet performance requirements such as fatigue life (stress constraints), manufacturing constraints and dynamic response. In the proposed Phase II effort, we will refine the user-足interface and extend the functionalities to integrate all key elements into a field-足ready commercial package that enables both expert and non-足expert designers to create compliant design solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Made in USA - Profitably: An Integrated Software Design Tool for Eliminating Assembly.

In this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project, we developed a software tool for designing single-piece compliant devices that provide mechanical functions like conventional mechanical devices do with assemblies of multiple rigid parts. Figure 1 shows several part-count reduction examples by incorporating compliant designs. By replacing multi-part assemblies with single-piece compliant designs that have substantially fewer parts and lower assembly burden, it can make domestic manufacturing a more appealing business proposition. However, currently, designing a compliant device involves using multiple software packages and custom scripts, making it difficult for less experienced engineers and designers to incorporate compliant designs into their systems and products. The objective of this project is to create a unified software tool to fulfill this need in the market.

The funding from NSF has enabled the development of the graphical user interfaces (GUI) and the design and optimization algorithms that are core to the software. Three modules were created for different user experience levels:

1)     FlexWorksOnline™: A cloud-based, introductory version for novice users to create simple compliant devices with minimal user inputs;

2)     FlexWorks Automated Design Module: A downloadable desktop edition that is an extension of the cloud version but with more design freedom for intermediate users to modify the various parameters used in the design algorithm; and

3)     FlexWorks Advanced Design Module: A desktop edition where expert users can sketch up design concepts and run custom optimizations.

The introductory and intermediate versions are both available for free at www.FlexToFunction.com (Figure 2). Figure 3 shows the FlexWorksOnline™ GUI. The Advanced Design Module will be downloadable for a fee, but is pending market feedback on the two deployed versions.

Since the launching of the Flex-to-Function website on March 15, 2017, we have received 1,122 visits to the website with a 1.5% CTR (Click Through Rate) from social media campaigns. Web analytics have also shown that nearly 12% of the unique visitors used the FlexWorksOnline™ design tool, and almost 30% of those who tried FlexWorksOnline™ requested to download the FlexWorks Automated Design Module. Considering that the typical industry benchmark conversion rates are 1-3%, the initial response to our web campaign was very encouraging.

Figure 4 shows a roadmap of future modules for the FlexWorks design tools. While the business case for the advanced software package and future modules is forthcoming, the Flex-to-Function website together with the introductory and intermediate versions of FlexWorks available to the public at no-cost will continue to improve the understanding and promote the application of compliant designs.
